ITEM 1. BUSINESS.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 1. BUSINESS section in bullet points:

• Affirm was founded in 2012.
• The company has charged $0 in late fees for missed payments since its founding.
• Affirm's proprietary technology can price and assess risk at a transaction level, providing a unique advantage compared to legacy payment and credit systems.
• The company's risk management models have been built on extensive data points from approximately 215 million loans.
• As of June 30, 2024, Affirm had approximately 303 thousand active merchants across various industries.

Item 1A. Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART I - Item 1A. Risk Factors section in bullet points:

• If AFRM is unable to attract commercial partners, retain existing partners, and grow new relationships, its business would be materially and adversely affected.
• The company relies on a small number of commercial partners (Celtic Bank, Lead Bank, and Evolve Bank & Trust) for loans facilitated through its platform; loss of any significant relationship could harm the business.
• AFRM's success depends on working with originating bank partners to effectively underwrite loans and accurately price credit risk.
• The company may not be able to sustain revenue and GMV growth rates or key operating metrics in the future.
• AFRM relies on various funding sources; failure to renew or replace existing arrangements could have a material adverse effect on its business.
• Loans facilitated through the platform do not perform, underperforming loans could result in financial losses and impact the company's financial condition and results of operations.

ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY section in bullet points:

• AFRM has established a cybersecurity program informed by the National Institute of Standards and Technology Cybersecurity Framework (NIST CSF).
• The program includes automated and manual testing of systems for vulnerabilities, monitoring and responding to suspicious activity, and penetration testing.
• AFRM conducts regular reviews and tests, including tabletop and red team exercises, to evaluate the effectiveness of its cybersecurity program.
• External auditors and consultants are periodically engaged to assess AFRM's cybersecurity programs.
• Affirm employees participate in mandatory cybersecurity awareness training to enhance their awareness of cybersecurity threats and best practices.
• The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is responsible for assessing and managing AFRM's cybersecurity risk management program, with an average of over 20 years of prior work experience in relevant roles.
• The CISO makes periodic reports to the Audit Committee regarding cybersecurity incidents and mitigation efforts.

ITEM 2. PROPERTIES..summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 2. PROPERTIES. section in bullet points:

• AFRM leases facilities under operating leases with various expiration dates through 2030.
• The company's corporate headquarters is located in San Francisco, California.
• Additional leased office space is located in:
  • New York, New York
  • Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania
  • Chicago, Illinois
  • Toronto, Ontario
• AFRM does not own any real property.

Item 3. Legal Proceedings.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 3. Legal Proceedings section in bullet points:

• AFRM may be subject to other legal proceedings and claims in the ordinary course of business.
• There are no currently pending legal proceedings that, if determined adversely to AFRM, would individually or taken together have a material adverse effect on its business, results of operations, financial condition, or cash flows.
• The outcome of any current or future litigation cannot be predicted with certainty.
• Defense and settlement costs, diversion of management resources, and other factors can have an adverse impact on AFRM regardless of the outcome.

ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT'S COMMON E.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT'S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES in bullet points:

• AFRM's Class A common stock is traded on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol "AFRM".
• As of August 23, 2024, there were 252 stockholders of record of AFRM's Class A common stock.
• As of August 23, 2024, there were 174 stockholders of record of AFRM's Class B common stock.
• AFRM has never declared or paid cash dividends on its capital stock and intends to retain future earnings to finance business operations.
• No equity securities were repurchased by the issuer or affiliated purchasers during the fourth quarter of 2024.
• The cumulative total stockholder return on AFRM's Class A common stock (January 13, 2021 - August 23, 2024) was $100 invested at market close on January 13, 2021.

ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANAL.summary:
Here are the key facts from the MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS section, formatted as bullet points:

• The fiscal year ended June 30, 2024 financial condition and results of operations discussion is presented in this report.
• A discussion regarding the fiscal year ended June 30, 2023 financial condition and results of operations can be found in "Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" in Part II, Item 7 of the Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended June 30, 2023.
• The company is building the next generation payment network using modern technology, strong engineering talent, and a mission-driven approach.
• Affirm's point-of-sale solutions allow consumers to pay in fixed amounts without deferred interest, late fees, or penalties.
• The platform facilitates both true 0% APR payment options and interest-bearing loans for consumers.
• Merchants can use the platform to promote and sell their products more efficiently, optimize consumer acquisition strategies, and drive incremental sales.
• Affirm's solutions provide valuable product-level data and insights to merchants, which they cannot easily get elsewhere.

ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DI.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK:

• As of June 30, 2024, $1.1 billion of marketable debt securities with maturities greater than three months were available for sale at fair value.

• An increase in interest rates would have an adverse impact on the fair market value of fixed rate securities and produce less income than expected from floating rate securities.

• The company's business strategy does not rely on generating material returns from its investment portfolio, and it expects its market risk exposure to be insignificant.

• A hypothetical instantaneous 100 basis point upward parallel shock to interest rates would have a less than $50.0 million adverse impact on the company's cash flows associated with its market risk-sensitive instruments over the next 12 months.

• The company relies on variable interest rate funding arrangements, which could reduce its interest margin earned in these arrangements if interest rates rise.

• Higher interest rates may lead to increased delinquencies, charge-offs, and allowances for loans and interest receivable, potentially affecting the company's operating results.

ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEM.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA section in bullet points:

• The financial statements of Affirm Holdings, Inc. and subsidiaries were audited by an independent registered public accounting firm.
• The audit was conducted in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB).
• The auditor expressed an unqualified opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of June 30, 2024.
• The financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of June 30, 2024 and 2023, and the results of its operations and cash flows for each of the three years ended June 30, 2024.
• The allowance for credit losses (ACL) is a material estimate used by management in estimating the ACL.
• The auditor conducted procedures to assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, including examining evidence regarding amounts and disclosures.

ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES section:

• As of June 30, 2024, AFRM's management, with the participation of CEO and CFO, evaluated the effectiveness of disclosure controls and procedures.
• The evaluation concluded that disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of June 30, 2024.
• Disclosure controls and procedures provided reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed in reports filed under the Exchange Act was recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within specified time periods.
• AFRM's management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting (ICFR).
• As of June 30, 2024, ICFR was evaluated based on criteria established by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in its Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013).

ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION in bullet points:

• On August 26, 2024, Michael Linford was appointed as Chief Operating Officer (COO) of AFRM, effective September 1, 2024.
• Katherine Adkins adopted a Rule 10b5-1 Trading Plan on June 13, 2024, allowing for the sale of up to 300,000 shares from September 12, 2024 until March 31, 2025.
• Noel Watson adopted a Rule 10b5-1 Trading Plan on June 14, 2024, allowing for the sale of up to 10,000 shares from September 13, 2024 until September 30, 2025.
• The Company entered into a Rule 10b5-1 Trading Plan on June 14, 2024, allowing for the repurchase of up to $400 million aggregate principal amount of its 0% Senior Convertible Notes due 2026 from August 1, 2024 until December 31, 2024.

ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS A.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE in bullet points:

• The Company's board of directors has adopted a Code of Ethics and Business Conduct (the "Code of Conduct") applicable to all officers, directors, and employees.
• The Code of Conduct is available on the Company's website (investors.affirm.com) under "Corporate Governance".
• The board of directors has also adopted an insider trading policy to promote compliance with insider trading laws, rules, and regulations.
• A copy of the Insider Trading Policy is filed as Exhibit 19.1 to this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
• The Code of Conduct will be updated in accordance with the disclosure requirement under Item 5.05 of Form 8-K, which will be posted on the Company's website within four business days following the date of any amendment or waiver.
